title: Initial Circulating Pressure (ICP)
content: Initial Circulating Pressure is the pressure you'll see on the drill pipe when you start circulating to kill the well. It's the sum of two things: the pressure needed to circulate at kill rate (SCR pressure) plus the formation pressure above what your current mud can handle (SIDPP). The formula is: ICP = SCR Pressure + SIDPP. You establish ICP by slowly bringing up the pump while holding casing pressure constant, then maintaining drill pipe pressure at ICP throughout the first circulation.

variables.ICP: Initial circulating pressure on drill pipe
variables.SCR Pressure: Slow circulating rate pressure (recorded before kick)

mcq.question: Your recorded SCR pressure at 30 SPM is 550 psi. After taking a kick, SIDPP stabilizes at 325 psi. What should your ICP be?
mcq.explanation: ICP = 550 + 325 = 875 psi. This is straightforward addition. The drill pipe pressure gauge should read 875 psi when you're circulating at kill rate and holding bottom hole pressure constant.

openQuestions: Why is it critical to record accurate SCR pressures before taking a kick?
What would happen if you started circulating before the well had fully stabilized?
l4Focus: As supervisor, ensure your crew records SCR pressures at multiple pump rates before entering the kick-prone zone. Having accurate data is essential when you need it.
